docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Sept. 9 Business Day article highlights a fact that health care pundits ignore: aging results in increased frequency of disease. Medicare health maintenance organizations didn't consider this when they enticed potential enrollees, promising enormous savings in premiums, while at the same time offering gifts like free prescription plans.
docs.abstract: Dr Robert Leval letter says September 9 Business Day article on woes of managed care underscored fact that aging results in increased frequency of disease--fact ignored by health care pundits, as well as health maintenance organizations when they enticed potential enrollees promising enormous savings in premiums (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A Sept. 9 Business Day article highlights a fact that health care pundits ignore: aging results in increased frequency of disease. Medicare health maintenance organizations didn't consider this when they enticed potential enrollees,...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: After five years of relatively slow growth, total spending on health care in the United States will climb briskly over the next decade, doubling by 2007, Federal officials said today. And in a reversal of recent trends, they said, private spending will grow faster than public outlays.

headline.main: Sharp Rise Predicted in Health-Care Spending in Next Decade

docs.abstract: Department of Health and Human Services predicts that total spending on health care will climb to $2.1 trillion in 2007 from slightly more than $1 trillion in 1997, with private spending growing faster than public outlays; says health care will account for 16.6 percent of gross domestic product in 2007, compared with 13.4 percent in 1997 (M)
